Addendum: I can't even appeal the @paypal denial because the case doesn't show up in my account.
@ericaberry2001 Except at least with olds you can usually find a way to talk to a human.

And because they closed the case, there's no easy way for me to remind them of all this info. Guess I'll see if Chase will treat it as fraud and do a chargeback to Paypal. Meanwhile, scammer still scamming. 4/4

I check the sellers site and find them using a rotating set of accounts to run this scan on others. Every time you put a purchase in your cart, it takes you to a different @paypal account to complete your transaction. I told @AskPayPal all of this, but they don't care. 3/4

It's a real @USPS tracker, for someplace in the town I live in, but it was issued prior to my purchase and wasn't sent to my address. I use Informed Delivery and that tracking number never showed in my account. My security cam from the day it was "delivered" shows no package. 2/4

The longer version of why @PayPal  sucks: I bought an item. Paid with Paypal on the website of the seller. Seller processes it as a cash advance, so I immediately get an extra $10 hit from my credit card. Shipper provides @USPS tracking number. 1/4

Damnit @paypal. Denying my case because the scammer provided somebody else's tracking number is crap. I can prove that package wasn't associated with my address thanks to USPS Informed Delivery and my security cam showing the mailman with no package.

@PaulAntesHarry Among other things, the very short news cycle. If a news org doesn't have somebody already on the ground, by the time they can get someone to a disaster struck area, consumers have already moved on to "the next big thing". We, the consumer, happened to old fashioned reporting.

@doyle0213 @MissAshes92 The reduced price is a benefit of membership, like reduced conference fees and concference discounts are. Members pay less for things the organization charges money for.
@MissAshes92 @doyle0213 It would be cool if someone came up with something free and sustainable. Others have tried, but ultimately found it couldn't be done on goodwill alone.
@MissAshes92 @doyle0213 Maybe you can work with AEMO or something to come up with an alternative.

@MissAshes92 @doyle0213 A lot of them don't require a degree to be certified for instance. Or they require different, or fewer, professional contributions. Or maybe no essay. Some are based solely on training, not on professional activities and experience.
@MissAshes92 @doyle0213 Trainings have gone virtual, increasing access, not limiting it. Be the change you want to see! Volunteer to be on the CEM commission and work from the inside.
@doyle0213 States often have their own programs that are cheaper and have different reqs than national or international ones. Your friend should look at state certification.

@doyle0213 Having an international certification program requires a lot of backend work that coordinates bodies of knowledge from around the world, to ensure that the right stuff is included for each region.

@doyle0213 The CEM body of knowledge is based on those same competencies, for the USA version at least. The CEM program itself is certified as well, based on an international standard for certification programs. I chuckle at the idea that we make "extra money" on the program or gain members

@doyle0213 My two ISO certs cost me $100/yr each to maintain, plus whatever CEUs I have to get. CEM ends up being cheaper because it requires less ongoing training and more professional contributions the longer you have it. And it averages to less money per year.

@doyle0213 Not true. You do not have to be a member to be certified. You do not have to go to conferences to be certified. You only have to pay the fee, take the test, and complete the other application requirements. And trust me, ALL certifications offered by a third party make money..
@doyle0213 And all of them count toward the certificate or recertification training requirements of most of the professional certifications (CEM, CBCP, CFP, some ISOs, etc).
@doyle0213 EFO is more on par with EMI's Advanced or Executive Academies, or the ELP at CHS. None of them are certifications though. They are all a program of study, which leads to a piece of paper.
@egyp7 @TProphet And if you do survive, you may well have a vastly different quality of life than you did before.
@doyle0213 What else is there beyond the training? CEM and other professional certs require a lot more than just training. Which is why they have to have review panels and such.

@doyle0213 The other option is for some other entity to create a certification and charge less for it. There have been some attempts, but it's hard to get people to do all the backend work for free, which is what low costs certs would require.
@doyle0213 So in the tech industry, you have to pay for your training and the cert costs. In EM, you only have to pay the cert costs. It's much cheaper to be a CEM than many other things.
@doyle0213 When I said tech, I was referring to technical certifications, like CISSP and stuff.

@doyle0213 I'm not clear on your question exactly. You can get all the training you need for the CEM for free. Your professional contributions are on you though. Most governments CAN accept grants, which is why FEMA was able to pay for many certs last year via IAEM.
@doyle0213 Is it NFPA directly or something else? Idle curiousity mostly.

@doyle0213 BTW, this is the exact same argument that exists in all of tech. Certs go to those who can afford them. It's a universal thing. IAEM did get a grant to pay for a bunch of local EMs to get them during the pandemic. And tech fundraisers often generate funds to pay for them.

@doyle0213 Is that a government issued certification for Fire? I know in our state it is. There's a big difference between technical government issued certifications and private ones. The CEM is the cheapest one I have at this point. Tech ones are crazy $$$.

@doyle0213 So the point in getting it is whatever you want it to be. Or nothing at all! It's like of like asking why an agency would become EMAP accredited. They found some value in it and went for it!

@doyle0213 As with most professional certifications, the point is to show that you have mastered a body of knowledge. It some markets, it can make you more competitive in the workforce. For some of us, it's a marker of our commitment to the continued professionalization of the field.

@jeffrubin2 @CourtOfDisaster @SamLMontano @AnthonyOnTheMap @katythewolf @seeleysue @Ready_Northwest @EM_millennials Yeah, it really depends. I got my first EM job absolutely because I had an MPA/EM degree. The people I eventually hired had degrees in a variety of things and came from a variety of backgrounds/experience.

@CourtOfDisaster @SamLMontano @AnthonyOnTheMap @katythewolf @jeffrubin2 @seeleysue @Ready_Northwest @EM_millennials It's important to recognize too that not everybody goes to school to get a new job. Sometimes they go because they just want to (hence my 83 year old BAS graduate), sometimes because they want to learn about a field they're already in.

@CourtOfDisaster @SamLMontano @AnthonyOnTheMap @katythewolf @jeffrubin2 @seeleysue @Ready_Northwest @EM_millennials No, but they might want one. There's a school near here that offers a planning degree with a minor in resilience (or something like that). It's a GREAT combo. Those people get jobs.

@CourtOfDisaster @EM_millennials @SamLMontano @AnthonyOnTheMap @katythewolf @jeffrubin2 @seeleysue @Ready_Northwest I can drive 30 minutes north and make $120K for a county or a large city. I can drive 30 minutes south and make $60k for similar work. Or stay in my own city and make $80k. NOTE: I'm not actually doing any of the above!

@Ready_Northwest @jeffrubin2 @SamLMontano @CourtOfDisaster @AnthonyOnTheMap @katythewolf @seeleysue @EM_millennials Or people who really just needed to join Team Rubicon or something because they want to help people muck out their homes after a flood.

@CourtOfDisaster @EM_millennials @SamLMontano @AnthonyOnTheMap @katythewolf @jeffrubin2 @seeleysue @Ready_Northwest or even different agencies in the same basic area. Here in WA, the state pays HORRIBLY. The counties and cities around pay much better. But the state relies upon new grads and those leaving the military. Those people stay a few years and leave for better pay.

@jeffrubin2 @SamLMontano @CourtOfDisaster @AnthonyOnTheMap @katythewolf @seeleysue @Ready_Northwest @EM_millennials AND a lot of people who get into the programs don't understand what they're getting in to. "It sounded cool" is never a good reason to pick a major.

@CourtOfDisaster @SamLMontano @AnthonyOnTheMap @katythewolf @jeffrubin2 @seeleysue @Ready_Northwest @EM_millennials I don't think it's a small field, especially if we reframe it as "emergency management professionals" instead of "emergency managers". There are a LOT of people doing related work in their own fields.

@SamLMontano @CourtOfDisaster @AnthonyOnTheMap @katythewolf @jeffrubin2 @seeleysue @Ready_Northwest @EM_millennials Yes, also this. Wages are all over the place, many were low to start with, and none are keeping up with the cost of housing.

@SamLMontano @CourtOfDisaster @AnthonyOnTheMap @katythewolf @jeffrubin2 @seeleysue @Ready_Northwest @EM_millennials A number of these programs get started because there's a federal report that lumps homeland security in with EM where jobs are concerned. So it counts things like "TSA Officer" in the same category as emergency manager.

@RealSexyCyborg I teach a class on Risk Perception and Risk Communication for @GeorgetownEDM. Just published a paper on the cognitive dissonance piece. It's related to disasters, but the premise is the same.  https://t.co/SziwWUkFMs

@RealSexyCyborg People's perception of risk is also based on their own experiences and how they think those experiences relate to the current situation, even if it's not the same. Many people still equate COVID to the flu because they were lied to. That's hard to change.
@RealSexyCyborg Change, not chance. Ugh.

@RealSexyCyborg To affect chance requires long-term messaging to change behavior. Public health has done a great job of long-term behavior change (seat belts, smoking, etc.) bud short term is very hard. Requires the message receiver to perceive benefit to themselves or someone they care about.

@RealSexyCyborg In part, yes. Cognitive dissonance plays role, where the brain acknowledges that bad things happen, but the default setting is they don't happen to "me", they happen to "you", so you should take some action. We see this in all sorts of places, including infosec, health, disasters

@DethVeggie Your eyes will thank you when you get it dialed in!
@DethVeggie Yeah, that seems to be about the standard unless you ask for something else.

@DethVeggie That's the exact convo to have with the doc. For some reason, they write them for way closer distances. If they write for 3, it will be even better when you're closer. Mine work great on desktop and make my eyes very happy on laptop. I'm opinionated about glasses! 43 years exp!

@DethVeggie Measure. It makes a huge difference. My computer glasses are measured. My everything else glasses are not. The difference is remarkable. And if they blow you off, go elsewhere. Doc needs to write the scrip based on the distance.

@DethVeggie Did you measure from your nose to the screen and have them made for that distance? That can be a key to success. Reading and computer glasses are not the same thing. Different focal points. You might like progressives, which are cheap at Costco.

@maxiesgal @BCWildfireWkly @Metcom_911 It's actually the same now. Level 2 is Warning (be ready) and Level 3 is GO NOW (mandatory). The thing is that new fires are popping up that unrelated to the big ones, which is why some people are getting GO NOW when maybe they weren't expecting it.

@maxiesgal @BCWildfireWkly @Metcom_911 These are the general evacuation areas. They probably got a knock because there was a fire encroaching on their specific location. Since they were at Level 2, they should have been ready to go when that knock came.

@arrowhags @Jortoise The Oregon ones were mostly started by a windstorm that caused power lines to spark. The only way to prevent that is to cut the power before the wind, which they have been trying in California. But shutting on the power in the middle of extreme heat also kills people.

@arrowhags Canada does have massive fires, but they are further north, so it is generally cooler there. And can't water an entire state except with rain. Which there is a lack of. Climate change has made a big impact on when the rain falls too, so there's been extra vegetation die off.

@ARMYBDYGUARD the thing is that we know from experience and research that not everyone can or will leave. There's severe inequity in people's ability to evacuate, even when they know they should. The next 48 hours there are going to be bad.

@ARMYBDYGUARD The message gets modified to be applicable to specific cities, who transmit it through a variety of channels, including social service orgs, faith communities, neighbors, etc. When your neighbor calls and says "we gotta go and I'll give you a ride", that's the motivator.

@ARMYBDYGUARD It's not designed to be heard through "the media" in the national sense. It's designed to be broadcast through local media and trusted agents in local communities, where people are used to getting reliable information from. Local media has much less doom.
And getting out of the way is no easy task, especially in COVID, especially in a location where people don't have their own transportation. Especially when they don't know where they will go.

As a risk communicator, this is good language to use, along with the rest of the message. It lays out the threat, the consequences, and tells people an action to take. It's up to people in the community, and local officials, to get themselves and others out of harms way.

As an emergency manager, part of the reason this is terrifying is that we know right now there are people who will not or cannot evacuate. Despite the very best messaging from NWS and local officials. There will be loss of life.

@DMQuayle @TheFireTracker2 @inquarters14 @NickArnett @QTRResearch I teach it as a graduate class and I have a paper co-authored and pending publication. Do EM and cybersecurity and it applies equally to both.
@DMQuayle @TheFireTracker2 @inquarters14 @NickArnett @QTRResearch And what we teach PIOs and other communicators doesn't account for that.

@DMQuayle @TheFireTracker2 @inquarters14 @NickArnett @QTRResearch Part of this difficulty is the role of cognitive dissonance. We're telling people things that are counter to what they believe to be true. Until they find a reason to set aside those beliefs and replace them with actual facts, they won't.
@TheFireTracker2 @inquarters14 @DMQuayle @NickArnett @QTRResearch Perception is reality for everybody. Our task is to change their perception to one that is a accurate and useful.

@EMgrB @triecker @seeleysue @dave_doors Most first responder orgs don't fully implement ICS that often. They struggle once they get into a second ops period. They never train for that.
@triecker @dave_doors @EMgrB @seeleysue And we do things like "combo classes", which take the key concepts of 100, 200, 700 and cram them into 6 hours.

@dave_doors @triecker @EMgrB @seeleysue Had convo with someone last week where they are starting to change this, at least for key players. They will no longer accept the FEMA online ICS training certs, in lieu of a state offered in-class one with practical application.

@dave_doors @triecker @EMgrB @seeleysue See my other comment. Plus, the actual required training is too short and doesn't include appropriate activities. And our organizations fight is on that. To do it right takes more time than they're willing to spend on it. At the end of the day, it's just not a priority.

@triecker @dave_doors @EMgrB @seeleysue My biggest issue as a city EM was staff turnover. We couldn't do exercised that built on the last ones because we had new people every time. The multi-year exercise plan for us never got beyond basics.

@triecker @dave_doors @EMgrB @seeleysue And that's something unlikely to ever be solved. Most people who take an ICS class (because they are required to), will never end up using it on a large scale event where it actually matters. And so we have a steady stream of non-proficient people trying to implement a system.
@_durandal_ @malanalysis @BadassBowden Your Princess Bride quotes will be gotten by me all day. Bring them on!

@triecker @EMgrB @dave_doors @seeleysue Healthcare has also tweaked it and calls it HICS. And part of the reason ICS struggles is because EOCs and similar things try to implement it and it was never designed for that. It's for incident response, not incident support.

@dave_doors @GabeLugoEM I think part of this argument is based on the idea that emergency response experience is the same as emergency management experience, when it is not. EM is the admin function that supports response. You have to learn to do research, write reports, write plans, write grants.

@dave_doors @GabeLugoEM Been having this argument for 20 years. It's old. Experienced emergency managers are the only people who get to apply for jobs based on experience. @alixtrot @densaer I did a talk in ethics in disaster tech. One of my points was that we have to account for the people that our solutions don't help AND the people who are made worse by our solutions AND we have to fix our solutions or create additional ones. Have to do more than think about it.

Existing network of people, vendors, and others to assist. Lack of ego (knows when they're in over their heads and willing to say so). JIT redundancies. Probably more, but those seem to be the highlights.

The "not great but ok" side of the coin has a multi-disciplinary response plan that they've trained an exercised on. Ability to recognize and isolate an incident. Continuity plan that keeps basic functions going. Ability to organize. Willingness to seek and accept assistance.

Sometimes loss of key people mid-incident. Lack of organized response. Unwillingness to loop in everyone in the org who can help solve the problem (s). Ignoring or rejecting valid offers of internal and external assistance.

I'm going to expand on this: shit widely encompasses the inability to quickly recognize an incident, lack of expertise to deal with it, lack of a list of people to call for help, no continuity plan (can't continue basic org functions like payroll), irretrievable data/work loss.

@Sieve70 Human brain: nothing bad has ever happened, so nothing bad ever will. It's the exact same problem we have in infosec. "I never thought it could happen to me" is the common refrain. I'm working on some research right now too try to figure out an answer!
@Sieve70 Plenty of things have less than 2 hour notice, depending on where you live: lahar, earthquake, fast moving fire, landslide, dam failure, flash floods.
@Sieve70 My folks live two houses from my sister, on purpose, but everyone is gone during the day. In think about this A LOT.

@Sieve70 Most of my parents neighbors work during the day. Maybe all of them at this point. And in a fast moving event, there would be no way to get to my mom. There are only about 6 neighbor houses in a reasonable distance.
@Sieve70 And they absolutely won't move to places where there are others options because they are self-reliant. Except when they're not.

@Sieve70 And then there's simple things. Like my folks. They're pretty self reliant, but they don't have extra cash and my mom can't drive anymore. If she got an evac order when my dad wasn't home and the neighbors weren't either, she'd be stuck.
@Sieve70 I can't tell you the number of times I had to explain to people that the big pretty mountain was actually a volcano that would someday try to kill them.

@Sieve70 Except we have a LOT more people concentrated in smaller spaces. And we've built into places that are known hazards, and into places we didn't know were hazards until after we built. AND there's no requirement to tell people about hazards when the move into a place.
@jamesburke54 I've flown more than 100k already this year. And not done.

@Sieve70 It's not just California and it's not just fires. We have huge amounts of research accumulated that point us at the problem. We lack the collective will to do anything about it. Requires better communication methods, better planning, more resources.

from what a fully functional democratic republic should be. In so many ways, we let the terrorists win. And collectively, we don't seem to care. Never forget the country we could be. The ideal we could be working toward. 6/ 7

@MissAshes92 @SarahDeYoung2 @CBRNEmedic Ugh. So many typos there.

@MissAshes92 @SarahDeYoung2 @CBRNEmedic AND, there's the financial issue. If my smaller jurisdiction opens up everything we have, that costs us a lot of money, which we never recoup if we're outside the disaster area.
@MissAshes92 @SarahDeYoung2 @CBRNEmedic Yep, but full is full and you have to keep driving.

@MissAshes92 @SarahDeYoung2 @CBRNEmedic I remember a planning meeting where I started that my city in the valley way going to evacuate uphill in a flood. The uphill city said we couldn't. I asked if they understood human nature!

@MissAshes92 @SarahDeYoung2 @CBRNEmedic And that right there is exactly the point! In addition to your own population, how many evacuees and their pets do you plan for AND have capacity for? If an extra 1000 pets show up in your town, can you care for them or do they have to keep driving?

@MissAshes92 @SarahDeYoung2 @CBRNEmedic Plan writing and plan execution are two different things. And for something like a Florida Hurricane, you're really asking GA, AL, SC to have plans, not Florida. At least for storms aimed mid--to-north Florida.

@MissAshes92 @SarahDeYoung2 @CBRNEmedic I saw the Texas plan in action during Harvey. It kind of stunk. Closest human shelter to where we were was 40 miles away and didn't take pets. People trying to recover had to schlep. Many just left and never came back. It was nearly a week before I saw a dog.

@MissAshes92 @SarahDeYoung2 @CBRNEmedic One of my grad students just wrote her thesis on animal sheltering. She found that local jurisdictions were doing a much better job of this than state level ones!

@MissAshes92 @SarahDeYoung2 @CBRNEmedic It's in most plans that I've seen. But again, the capacity that any one government has is less than their actual need in most cases. AND they are planning for their own population, not an evacuated population from elsewhere.
@SarahDeYoung2 @MissAshes92 @CBRNEmedic The entire shelter system, for people and animals, requires multi-sector effort. It's more it less spelled out in the National Mass Care Strategy.
@SarahDeYoung2 @MissAshes92 @CBRNEmedic Government can't provide sufficient people sheltering either, which is why the Red Cross is relied upon in so many places.

@SarahDeYoung2 @MissAshes92 @CBRNEmedic Government usually doesn't have the capacity. Most partner with non-profit animal groups for animal sheltering. Here, we have contracts with the big national animal non-profits to run co-located pet shelters. It's not a service that government can do directly.
@SarahDeYoung2 @MissAshes92 @CBRNEmedic Even Airbnb gets on-board with pet-friendly disaster housing! But you also have to been a bit more savvy to access it.

@MissAshes92 @SarahDeYoung2 @CBRNEmedic It's some of both. There's limited capacity for pets and they fill quickly. So you just have to keep going further, whereas if you didn't have pets, you might find something closer that wasn't yet full.
@MissAshes92 @SarahDeYoung2 @CBRNEmedic Also, what might have previously been a 4 hour drive might be 10 simply due to traffic.

@MissAshes92 @SarahDeYoung2 @CBRNEmedic It has changed, but it's capacity issue. In Texas, you can go multiple directions to evacuate. In Florida, you can basically go one. And much of that one direction is under evac orders also. When fam with pets left Florida for Irma, one went to TN and the other to AL. Long drive

I tell people the only reason I'm on @facebook is to watch out for the fam. It is increasingly true. 8/8.

the fake account isn't her. In the meantime, fake great-auntie is free to prey upon whomever they'd like to. So stupid Facebook. You now KNOW about a threat to vulnerable people and you won't do squat about it. 7/

the fake account, but they won't. They can clearly compare IP addresses and phone numbers and prove that those two people aren't the same. But no, they won't Not until an 80 year woman jumps through whatever hoops @faceook decides she needs to in order to prove 6/

impersonated.  Hows that even going to work? @facebook is just going to let fake great-auntie scam real great auntie's family and friends until what? They get her to respond on Messenger (which she doesn't use)? They have all the evidence they need to shut down 5/

I've been trolling fake great-auntie the whole time, just to see what happens. They helpfully confirm that my deceased grandmother is just fine. I report them again to @facebook. They finally respond that they'll get in touch with great-auntie to confirm she's really being 4/

I warn the fam and tag her on Facebook. She's nearly 80, as are her cousins and other family members. They don't know to poke around in the guts of the forsaken system to see that it's fake great auntie. I report to Facebook. They ignore me the first time. 3/

I answer, then "she" hits me with a scam. I'm like, WTF, this isn't my great auntie at all! When I pull up the full view of the Facebook convo, it shows her name and profile pic, but says it's a Messenger only account for someone who doesn't have Facebook.  2/

Here's a rant about @facebook. A couple of days ago, I got a PM from my great auntie in Facebook. I don't use messenger, so I could see it via web. It was a simple "how are you doing" which is a totally legit thing for my great auntie to say.  1/

@actualreverend @CoconinoSheriff @NAUPolice It is in parts of the country. Slow rollout since PSAPs have to have correct tech in place. And location data is not transmitted.
And now turbulence. I'm really hungry. Very near to #hangry   I had lunch like 10 hours ago.
Can somebody explain to me why our country is talking about buying other countries? We can't even afford the payments on the one we have.

@actualreverend @CoconinoSheriff @NAUPolice So we can choose from township/range/section, lat/long, Thomas guide, or words. Because numbers are hard. I'm still cranky that the Thomas Guide replaced the other two!
@actualreverend @CoconinoSheriff @NAUPolice I have a general beef with people who go outside things and don't learn to read or use maps. Also, get off my lawn!
@actualreverend @CoconinoSheriff @NAUPolice That's a different use case which makes sense to me!

@actualreverend @CoconinoSheriff @NAUPolice My main beef is that the most likely places for people to get lost in the US are also places that have no cell or data coverage. And if they do have coverage, their lat/long is transmitted with their 911 call.

@actualreverend @CoconinoSheriff @NAUPolice Oh God. I just had a huge flap on the Facebook with somebody about this. It's cool and all, but I don't think we need yet another thing for our 911 call takers to have to deal with. Maybe other use cases though.

I think things got a little crazy in ATC when we were taxiing around still too. We made a VERY hard stop. I looked out and there was a giant Lufthansa plane close and perpendicular to us that had just done the same thing. It turned it's lights off and we continued on.

And we're on our way!  Overhead bin door popped open right after takeoff. Flight attendant had to jump up and secure it. Assuming nothing else happens, arrival delay will be 2 hours 17 minutes. #iFlyAlaska
@DisasterEeek I thought the same until I came across those skunks!!
Here we go for real!!
@DisasterEeek Be sure to watch for the little skunk family. They are adorable!
@McSev Ohhhhhh. That also means an extra day of per diem! Silver lining.
@McSev Luckily I don't have an early meeting tomorrow. It will be well after midnight before I get home.
Also, I'm hungry. Really hungry.
@AccessRadioDJ People had almost two hours in which to get off! A mom and kid did. The rest of us stuck it out

Finally taxiing around the airport. There are planes parked *everywhere*. It looks like everything that can be considered an empty space has a plane in it. We are now one of them, with an ETA for actual takeoff of 21:18.
The door did in fact close. But there are so many planes sitting around we can't push back. Been on the plane 2 hours now.
Woohoo! Door closing!!
Been sitting on the plane for an hour and 45 minutes. I just hope the crew doesn't time out or anything . . .
@McSev At least then I'd have a snack and a drink!! I love watching thunderstorms from the air though. So amazing!
@McSev It was super nasty!! And we're still sitting here in the backup . . .
I think every kid on the plane just went up for a cockpit tour. At least the pilots aren't bored now.

Interesting. The final passenger just got on this plane. We were supposed to leave nearly an hour ago. Heard convo from crew that she had a major TSA hassle. She's young too. Clearly a teen  The delay worked out for her at least. Though the hassle did not.
OUCH. New ETA is that we'll leave in 50 minutes. That's a big ATC delay. And I'm really hungry. #iFlyAlaska

The storm has cleared and everybody is back out on the ramps. But there's a huge backlog of flights waiting for final prep and a spot in line. Our last ETA for departure was 5 minutes ago. Door still open, pilots roaming around looking bored.

I've been to the Auschwitz memorial. I read the names of people who had the same last name as my family. I don't know if we were related, but I know they were murdered there. The young people on our trip thought every person their age should visit and learn.
Yikes. Just when it looked like the weather was going to clear, lighting strike just off (or maybe on) the tarmac.

Preventing a car from reaching the legal speed limit is ridiculous. I thought I was going to get run down by a semi that barreled up behind me. Yes, he should have backed off, but I should have had the option to speed up and give him space. I didn't. 5/

They programmed the car to go to faster than 65.  It also beeped every time it hit 50, 55, or 65 and popped up a message that had to be cleared. Not only was this hugely distracting, but also dangerous. 4/  https://t.co/x7J6k7YkD5
WTAF is a vehicle top speed?? Then I hit 65 and realized this was not a limitation of the car, but a choice by Hertz. 3/  https://t.co/gUpCYYMh1J
WTF is that? And this is displayed on the info screen.  I thought this odd, but mostly annoying. Then I hit 55 MPH. 2/  https://t.co/x7YXnFGml3

@Maliciouslink We don't typically provide infosec pros with any sort of risk communication training though, relying on "I told you to" as the primary motivator. Which isn't effective.
@Maliciouslink It's a class that's part of a disaster management program. The concepts are exactly the same in infosec though. "I never thought it could happen to me" is the common refrain.
@Maliciouslink "internalizing'

@Maliciouslink People accept risk all around them every day for precisely this reason. They are aware of the potential of bad things, but their brain tells them the the risk is to other people. I teach a whole graduate class on risk perception. Internalized the risk leads to better choices.

also not a hugger. Watching my physical reaction, and hearing my adult description of what happened, helped him understand the much loved young lady in his life. So yay for that! Ultimately, this ends up being a conversation about consent, couched in terms of a hug. 8/

I know I don't have to justify those choices, but I often feel like I'm obligated to, like somehow I'm the weirdo for not hugging. And I'm glad I did. Someone came up to me afterward and noted that they have a granddaughter or a niece [my bad for not remembering which] who is 7/

It was truly hilarious. It was also, thankfully, a safe space. I think he initially thought I was reacting to him, but I was actually reacting to a dreaded hug. So I made him feel bad, which made me feel bad, but then I also felt like I had to explain why I'm not a hugger. 6/

He first seemed to think maybe I was joking. And was legit confused when I was not. I could hear my co-instructors "she's not a hugger", trying to now get us all out of this highly awkward situation. He's looking at me, I'm looking at him, and still apparently backing up. 5/

I thought it was a joke. I've never seen him hug anybody. In an instant I knew it was not a joke. I was wholly unprepared for this and my entire being reacted accordingly. I slowly (or maybe not) backed away. Somebody said later they thought I was going to mow down an easel. 4/

Today I was with a group of people I've spent about 3 weeks with over the past 8 months. I'm teaching. There was a role play. I was the boss and my employees were trying to convince me to do something. Their appointed spokesperson said he was going to hug me.  3/

This is usually not an issue. I keep an eye out for serial huggers. When I see them headed for me, I stick my arm out to shake hands. They can shake my hand, impale themselves on it, or try to do a really awkward hug. Most opt for the shake. Nobody yet has opted for impale. 2/

I'm not a hugger. My friends and the people I spend a lot of time around know this. I'm not anti-hugging. I DO hug people, just not a lot of them. I'm related to most of them, or have known them for a long time, or we've connected over something emotional (like a disaster). 1/

@phildavis55 @KeithKOMO4 @komonews And for small businesses and non-profits, using cloud hosted email as opposed to a server in the closet is the way to go. Leaves pros running the security AND your email isn't lost if you do have an incident. Non-profits can get Office 365 or Google Enterprise free!
@phildavis55 @KeithKOMO4 @komonews Using antivirus software is important, but they all essentially scan for the same things, so you go with the one that offers the features you like best.

@phildavis55 @KeithKOMO4 @komonews The best defense against malware (including ransomware) is good online hygiene. Don't click links unless you're certain of their content, don't open emails from unknown or suspicious senders, don't plug in USB storage devices that aren't yours, use pop-up and ad blockers.
@phildavis55 @KeithKOMO4 @komonews For what purpose? Security software is a really broad concept!

@Southrn_Melle @MissAshes92 I have three professional certs, all with continuing ed reqs. I look for classes that can count toward all 3. Gets expensive otherwise.
@MissAshes92 @triecker @Southrn_Melle It's the same with every social science that has a degree. Getting a degree in criminal justice doesn't make you a cop. Still have to go to the academy!
@MissAshes92 @triecker @Southrn_Melle Theory vs practice. We need both!
@Southrn_Melle @MissAshes92 Bingo!

@MissAshes92 @Southrn_Melle Cool! My state has no certification. Hell, we barely have a state association. I haven't been able to pay my dues in a year because their website is broken and they won't tell anybody how to pay!!

@triecker @MissAshes92 @Southrn_Melle No worries! A couple of weeks ago, somebody who tried to get their CEM 15 years ago (and has since retired) cornered me at a conference to bitch about the degree requirement! :P
@triecker @MissAshes92 @Southrn_Melle I don't disagree! Though I can't speak to the state piece, just trying to meet people and make a network was hard.
@MissAshes92 @Southrn_Melle Yep. And that's what trips up a lot of people. They want response years to count the same as EM years. Different job . . .
@MissAshes92 @Southrn_Melle But they do want the TEM that has the same reqs as the AEM and that the same person with 5 years experience also can get.

@MissAshes92 @Southrn_Melle I remember talking about it somewhere publicly right after they changed it. Some guy was pissed because he didn't have a degree. I asked "why didn't you apply last year then" and he really has no answer. He just wanted to bitch about it!
@MissAshes92 @Southrn_Melle I know. It's just an old argument. 15 years old in fact!

@MissAshes92 @Southrn_Melle They should have applied with 20 years of experience, before there was a degree requirement!! Also, we have the AEM for them. Many states have their own certs, though it's not a substitute. It's a different cert.

@MissAshes92 @Southrn_Melle Hopefully the people dropping membership are joining your state association. I've found that most people who drop never took the time to get involved, thus got very little out of their membership. Part of my job as Region president is to ask everybody who leaves why!

@MissAshes92 @triecker @Southrn_Melle Have you asked? If you send a note to info@iaem.com, they can provide a lot of specific info. In general, this is the first price hike in many years, so you can sort of do the math related to cost of living since the last increase.
@triecker @MissAshes92 @Southrn_Melle As a 501(c)3, tax returns are also public record.
@triecker @MissAshes92 @Southrn_Melle The budget is available, at both the regional and USA level.

@tamer_hadi @MaryJoFly @MissAshes92 @Clim8Resilient @iaem @IAEMETC @EMCESA I have three different, complimentary, certifications. One of them is the CEM. For me, the value is in knowing that I'm directly contributing to improving the profession. I learned long so not too try to convince someone of something they've declared they don't like!
@Clim8Resilient @MaryJoFly @tamer_hadi @iaem @IAEMETC @EMCESA There was only one level of credential for a long time. Now two. Maybe someday three!
@MissAshes92 @Clim8Resilient @MaryJoFly @tamer_hadi @iaem @IAEMETC @EMCESA There's a movement afoot to start a caucus for small organizations. It just takes a few people to get things moving.

@MissAshes92 @Clim8Resilient @MaryJoFly @tamer_hadi @iaem @IAEMETC @EMCESA The T&E committee does a lot of work around theory-to-practice, which deals directly with that bridge. As to the rest,  new groups start when somebody suggests them, gets other people on-board, then asks to start the group! We're a member driven organization.

@MissAshes92 @Clim8Resilient @MaryJoFly @tamer_hadi @iaem @IAEMETC @EMCESA What do you want to get out of your IAEM membership? People find the most value in the caucuses and committees, but only about 1/4 of the members actually join one.
@Clim8Resilient @MaryJoFly @iaem @IAEMETC @EMCESA Also, have you thought about joining the CEM Commission? That's where these things get decided!
@Clim8Resilient @MaryJoFly @tamer_hadi @iaem @IAEMETC @EMCESA Then there's a third level (Advanced or MasterCard or something) that says "I've really got it".

@Clim8Resilient @MaryJoFly @tamer_hadi @iaem @IAEMETC @EMCESA The CEM was the baseline for a long time. After adding the degree requirement for it though, a lot of people were excluded. The AEM is the entry path to the CEM. This isn't an unusual model in certifications. The first level is "working on it", the middle level is "got it"

Some people harass because they're clueless. They can be changed. Some people harass because they're assholes. They can't be changed. Either way, harassment is pervasive and so very many people have to deal with it. We all need to be good allies and work to change this. 6/6

Bottom line, harassment is everywhere. It doesn't just happen to women. Recently watched it happen to a millennial man, because he was a millennial. He responded with cursing and a very direct statement to knock it off. I've watched it happen to LGBTQI friends & colleagues. 5/6

Emergency Management: age, gender, horribly sexist remarks in public and private, offended because I don't hug strangers, targeting my employees. HIgher ed: age (from peers) and all sorts of crazy shenanigans from students (mostly taken with a grain of salt, but still ...). 4/6

911 center: obnoxious cops with sexist remarks. ISP tech support: gender and age comments. Technical recruiter: being ignored based on age and gender. Another 911 center: a horribly toxic dude who raged at his co-workers about everything (gender, age, religion, clothing,. 3/6

I realized that I would never had kept a job if I had left every time I had been harassed (except for the college job where I washed cars for the sheriff's office). Picking berries as a kid: being catcalled. First real job (hospital): comments on my clothes and my youth.   2/6

Yesterday somebody (a guy) asked me earnestly why a woman would want to go back to a work environment where she had been harassed. My immediate answer was 1) so the assholes don't win and 2) because we need money. Having now slept on that question, I have a deeper answer. 1/6

Thanks for listening Twitter friends. I'm grateful the drugstore sells gin (Hendricks even!) and tonic and the hotel ice machine is working. And feel free to laugh and my derpy shower button story! 10/10

be forced to apologize to somebody (that happened recently). Mostly I'm just pissed. Sexism is so alive and well in our field, I feel like we breed it and nurture it instead of nuking it from orbit. If I bitch, I'll be the removed, not him, because he's the customer. Ugh. 9/10

I'm pissed because if he'll say that in public, he probably says worse in private. I'm pissed because he also went on a rant about transgender athletes that was BS (yes, I spoke up on that). I'm pissed because someone will probably get butthurt over this thread and I'll  8/10

I'm pissed I didn't say "that was inappropriate". I'm pissed that part of my thinking was whether I'd get canned for making waves. I'm pissed nobody else said anything. I'm pissed I'm going to have to see him every day for a week. I'm pissed that his employer employs him. 7/10

After we were done for the day, I talked to the other woman that was there to confirm that I didn't hear things wrong. I did not. She repeated verbatim what she heard from dude bro. I'm so pissed. I'm pissed he said it, over my literal protestations. 6/10

I started saying no over the top of his commentary, which became NO, which became "THAT IS NOT ME". He finished his "punchline" after my protests. Then there was awkward silence and somebody changed the topic. 5/10

Today I'm relating my story to some #emgtwitter colleagues at the class ( not class members). Dude bro "professional" starts laughing with everybody else, then adds his own commentary, about how I was just wearing a bath towel that I let slip off when maintenance got there. 4/10

I had to call the front desk, who had to send maintenance. It turns out those knobs with the symbols are buttons, not knobs. Dude pushes the button and water magically appears! He was kind enough not to laugh at me. :) 3/10

I wanted to fill the bathroom with steam and hang my clothes in there because I'm too lazy to iron. I could NOT figure out how to turn the shower on. There was an assortment of knobs and dials, but no combo made water come out! 2/10  https://t.co/5TNuCcMK7N

This is a story that starts funny and ends with something unfunny. I'm traveling for work this week, teaching a class. I got a really nice hotel upgrade to an exec suite. ... my goat needs to come live with your goats for a few days until I can figure this out". So Clover went and had a sleepover with the BFF's goats, where she was very happy. Niece got on Craigslist to find new goat buddies for Clover. 4/6

and chased the jogger lady down the street, screaming at her. Lady stopped, Clover caught up to her, and laid her head against her leg for comfort. Niece retrieved her and realized she had a crisis on her hands. Niece called her BFF and said "I have a goat emergency.  ... 3/6

@cybersecuriTiff Now I'm thinking this could be an interesting #defcon talk ...

@cybersecuriTiff exactly how it might affect them. That can be the trusted messenger explaining their own experience. Another tactic is showing how their action (or lack) affects the people they care about. My Aunt enabled 2FA after understanding risk to others.

@cybersecuriTiff I teach an entire graduate class on this exact topic! it is the bane of risk communicators everywhere. Part of the solution is for the message to come from people they perceive to be like themselves. And part of it is for them to see or experience a clear illustration of 1/2

@cybersecuriTiff They have to personalize it. Most people hear the risk and ascribe it to somebody who isn't them. They understand that there is risk, but internal bias tells them they are safe from it, but other people should definitely be taking action.
@cybersecuriTiff This is why I'm both an emergency manager and a cybersecurity manager! The parallels are striking.

@ShaunanKruse Also, this isn't panic! Panic is a lack of constructive action. People are taking steps in relation to the storm that they believe are needed to keep themselves safe and/or comfortable. That's the opposite of panic!

@ShaunanKruse Yes and no. People perceive this to be a huge risk to them, so they take action. They don't perceive an earthquake to be an actual risk, since they can't see it or any evidence of it. So their internal bias tells them they're safe.
I just hope the earthquake that could actually hurt people happens next week, while everybody is still stocked up .... 3/3

"Particularly perplexing is that even risk events with minor physical consequences often elicit strong public concern and produce extraordinarily severe social impacts, at levels unanticipated by conventional risk analysis" (Kasperson et al., 1988).  2/3

@TheEPSLdn @TheEPS1 @DGVost @VOSTeurope @NCSC Well, I'm more saying if you don't have a plan, and you haven't tested a plan, the resources don't matter much since you don't know how to access them our utilize them.
@CyberRangerM Yeah, not so much. You have to have a plan to know what to ask for. Our state has a response team, but you have to ask for it . . .
@Rubonist My smallest city is 7000, my largest about 110k.
@Rubonist It's a medium city with a fairly small government. Pretty typically of Seattle suburbs. Very wealthy and everybody commutes elsewhere to work.
@Ready_Northwest That is basically an annual event, but it's more a tabletop and the people who might get the most from it don't come.
@Rubonist About 65K.

@Rubonist There is. A request was made today, through non-standard channels, to get some resources. And they're getting help. But had there been a plan, tested and vetted through both IT and EM, I think maybe it would't have taken a week AND it might have gone through the normal channel.

@Rubonist By way of example, this current city has one IT staff person right now (sounds like maybe the other one quit mid-incident). They have to reimage 120 machines and rebuild their network infrastructure. And those things have been gone for a week now.

@Rubonist So for instance, if the water system can't distribute water anymore due to a cyber incident, ICT is going to fix that, but they're not going to arrange for shelters, water delivery, hospital re-routes/shutdowns, etc. That piece of consequence management falls to EM.

@Rubonist I have a lot of really small cities around me. They might have one person to do their "computer stuff". And that person is good at that job until something really bad happens. And they usually don't have the skills to deal with the human impacts to either employees or the public.
@Rubonist Also by "you" I meant the organization's overall plans, not any specific silo.

@Rubonist If planning is not done collaboratively with EM, there's no clear path to the consequence management of the stuff that goes beyond the ICT sphere. And worse yet, small cities often have no plans at all. EM can get the discussion started.

@Rubonist That has to be part of the discussion. One of the biggest problems I've seen in small orgs is that ICT doesn't recognize the complete impact of failure, nor do they have the responsibility or ability it deal with the cascsding consequences.

wanted to make sure Jeanne got her invitation! And that's how a neighborhood in Oregon banded together to find a women they'd never heard of to make sure she got a party invitation. Thank you kind Oregonians! 4/4

None of them knew Jeanne either, but they set out to find her. Somebody (Paula) hunted online until she found a likely candidate, then e-mailed that information to Alice, who printed it and mailed it back to me with the note. She thought the party sounded really fun and 3/4

The invitation had been opened and there was a note inside. Seems Alice doesn't know Jeanne, but she started to check around. She checked with the previous owner of the home, but they didn't know Jeanne either. So she checked with  all her neighbors. 2/4

Funny story about nice people I don't know: I've been sending mailed invites to my parents 50th anniversary party. I got an envelope in the mail today from a name I didn't recognize. A lady named Alice. In the envelope was an invitation I mailed to her address, but to Jeanne. 1/4

Safety requires that we engage, not only with our local, state, and federal elected officials, but with the tech makers as well. They all need to hear from emergency managers. #iaem18
Using all the technologies together in a coordinated reduces milling time since people hear the same info from multiple sources simultaneously. #iaem18
Question: how do we ensure companies are building safety into their tech products? #iaem18
Audience question: warning systems require education and training. Need appropriate response from those who receive them. #iaem18
Anything we do with technology is going to both fail and succeed initially. The goal is more successes than failures. #iaem18
Earthquake early warning could also provide automated tsunami warning for those who live close to coast. #iaem18
Possibility for earthquake early warning: open fire bay doors, self-driving fire engine moves itself out to safety while firefighters are doing "drop, cover, hold". #iaem18

Data and automation can push info to your phone when you enter a new area, such as a tsunami zone. Could include evac info. Can also go the other way and tell EM how many people are in the evac area and where they are. #iaem18
As @schuback is talking about home automation and devices, I'm watching a squirrel on my front porch via my camera that has automated notifications. #iaem18
The majority of our emergency operations should not be using paper anymore. Most of what we do can use databases, electronic forms. #iaem18
Home automation devices have the ability to tell us now if our homes have power and internet. We can check remotely. #iaem18
@schuback says we've eliminated fax machines. If only that were actually true . . . #iaem18  https://t.co/HKXIRg6wDD
Earthquake early warning allows us to use automation to protect things. What if a connected vehicle could move itself out of harm's way prior to the earthquake? #iaem18
Earthquake early warning is rolling out, but requires more education and training to be successful. #iaem18
Autonomous vehicles create an attractive target for criminal hackers. We have to be prepared for that. Cybersecurity is critically needed. #iaem18
Uncomfortable laughter in the room when @mdeyerin asks how many organizations in the room have ended up with technology bought by somebody who fundamentally didn't understand it. #iaem18
Autonomous vehicles will bring with them tremendous data. Are we prepared for that? Do we have the knowledge and skills to use it? #iaem18
Autonomous vehicles have the ability to create a hyper-effecient system for daily use, but it will have difficulty accounting for surge from unplanned events (like disasters). #iaem18
Autonomous vehicles will dramatically change society. Broad adoption will fundamentally change how our world works. #iaem18
Augmented reality can be particularly useful in recovery, where it can overlay what used to be there with what's there now. #iaem18
Augmented reality has great uses in EM. Drone footage with road and other data overlaid. #iaem18
5G requires massive investment in infrastructure. #iaem18
Autonomous vehicle tech will require 5G and meshed networks to be effective and widely used. They need to talk to each other among other things. #iaem18

Autonomous vehicles require extensive sensors. Those sensors have to stay clean to work. Can be challenging in a disaster environment. How about ash, fog, heavy snow, or unexpected road closures? #iaem18

Logistical needs may be met in the future via autonomous vehicles. Imagine your disaster supplies not having to stop for a sleep break on their way. Or the SNS rolling out on its own as soon as it's needed. #iaem18
Driverless cars can provide greater autonomy for people with access and functional needs. #iaem18 #iaemetc
Important idea: mapping alternative fuel sites. Critical need for people evacuating in electric cars. #iaemetc #IAEM18

@0xNBE1 Two books I like on this subject  https://t.co/SWoLe8BbhA Risk Communication: A Handbook for Communicating Environmental, Safety, and Health Risks  https://t.co/Pwg6vEphgq
@0xNBE1 That's almost exactly it. Sometimes it's language, sometimes it's concepts, sometimes it's just that nerds are alien beings from another planet.

@0xNBE1 I wouldn't say refuse. I would say can't. At least in the form it's being presented. I hear refuse a lot, but usually from people for whom the problem is obvious and glaring. And they get frustrated in trying to communicate it and take it as refusal.

@0xNBE1 Also, in general, communicating tech info to a non-tech audience is fraught with peril. It's easy to talk over the level of the audience OR treat them like they're stupid. Finding the sweet spot in the middle can be hard, especially for someone who isn't a trained communicator

@0xNBE1 I have many thoughts on this. One of the classes I teach is on risk perception and risk communication. And then I actually do those things in real life. Part of the issue is that people don't receive that THEY have risk and until they do, communication will prob fail.

@bfwriter @J70381415 @EthicsVillage But do people discard their deepest values? If the value is easily discarded, it probably wasn't one of your actual core values. People can usually list off a bunch of "things" they value, but those in and of themselves aren't values. They're still just things.

@J70381415 @bfwriter @EthicsVillage it's also important to recognize that some people WILL choose to walk away, knowing they can no longer put food on the table. That's the thing with values: we all have different ones and we will act according to what is most important to us. You can't force others to share yours.

Not a great work at home day. Now there are 6 gas company rigs outside, their phones ringing non-stop, radios talking, there's a concrete saw making a HUGE amount of noise, conversations everywhere. I me with the windows open because there's still a faint gas odor in here.
And bonus: since I don't have natural gas service, I'm good to go. Entire rest of the neighborhood has to go through the whole start-up process once they fix the line.
guy with the gas wand just came and made sure my house wasn't going to explode. Had already started ventilating, but it was probably ok anyway. Just had the lovely oderizer smell.
oh, and as I come in the house @ButtersOK crawls lazily out from under the bed, wondering if maybe he missed something ...
and kudos to @ValleyFire and @PSETalk for being right on this. From the time the firefighter pounded on my door until the time I was back home was only about half an hour.
As I'm walking up to my front door, I hear contractor boss say to contractor dude: I'd like to you do something right for once.   With the gas company employees all standing there listening.
Fire truck is leaving. I think that's my cue to go home .

@CrisisFocus @IAEMETC The ransomers also target healthcare because of the lax hygiene practices. Makes it easier to get. But again, that's the bad guy, not the ransomware itself.
@IAEMETC Interesting fact: most cyber ransomers are never caught. Mostly because incidents are never reported. #IAEM17
@IAEMETC Ransomware is equal opportunity: it doesn't discriminate between targets. #IAEM17
@IAEMETC Have an attack response plan: isolate infected device, secure backup data, activate incident response team. #IAEM17
@IAEMETC @eTechOps Prevention Activities: tested backup system, patch your stuff, upgrade plan for outdated devices. #IAEM17
@IAEMETC Ransomware is a business problem, not an IT problem. #IAEM17
@IAEMETC Next big thing in ransomware: IOT ransoms. Large police department had 60% of their security cameras held got ransom prior to a large event. #IAEM17
@IAEMETC Security Onion is a free intrusion detection system you can install to help you monitor what's going on in your network. #IAEM17
@IAEMETC Best practice: don't login to your computers with Admin privileges unless you're performing an admin task. #IAEM17
@IAEMETC Best method for ransomware prevention: good digital hygiene. Want help with this? Visit the Crisis Technology Center in booth 711. #IAEM17
@IAEMETC Key point: even if you pay the ransom, you may not get your data back. #IAEM17
@IAEMETC Many solutions to prevent ransomware are not difficult to implement, but you have to actually do it. #IAEM17

@IAEMETC @eTechOps Best practice: never open email attachments without confirming with the sender that the attachment is legit. And don't confirm via email, use the phone or text to a known number, not the one in the email. #IAEM17
@IAEMETC @eTechOps Large number of ransomware delivered via spam or malicious web links. Traditional antivirus software largely ineffective. #IAEM17
@IAEMETC @eTechOps Hundreds of ransomware variants. Some even have chat built in to help you communicate with the ransomer. #IAEM17
@IAEMETC @eTechOps Most ransomware payments are made in crypto currency, which is often reinvested in further attacks. #IAEM17
@IAEMETC @eTechOps $325 million paid last year to unlock ransomware. Average is $400-500 per unlock. Many people don't pay and either restore from backup or start over. #IAEM17
@IAEMETC @eTechOps The ransomware price list. How much will it cost you to regain control of your stuff? #IAEM17  https://t.co/TcYDOz4pIZ
@IAEMETC @eTechOps Research shows that hospitals are not attacked more often than other targets, but they lack the digital hygiene to protect themselves. #IAEM17

@SamLMontano We were operating out of bldg I knew would be condemned, but nowhere else to be. Was condemned week after we left. 6/6
@SamLMontano Complete destruction of many structures. They can't be fixed. Must be rebuilt, but sense is many under-insured. Or not insured. 5/
@SamLMontano Lack of understanding on part of local officials on how to report/track damage for reimbursement. Lack of timely ability to haul debris. 4/
@SamLMontano Heavy reliance on tourism, but no place for tourists to go now. Also many 2nd/3rd homes. No true local connection. 3/
@SamLMontano Rental owners not local. No connection/incentive to rebuild. Huge, expensive infrastructure damage. Small local budget already. 2/
@SamLMontano Key reasons I saw: Destruction of tax base. Larger renter population moved immediately. No jobs or homes to bring them back. 1/

ShelterBox does not deploy a lot to the United States, mostly because there are a lot of available assets already here. #iaem15
ShelterBox vols expected to be boots-on-the-ground within 48 hours of getting "the call". #iaem15
ShelterBox deploys in 2-person teams, with the intent of rapidly distributing tents to those who need them. #iaem15
After 4 days in outdoor training, those who make it through ShelterBox initial training go to England for 2 weeks for more training. #iaem15
Anybody can be a nice person for 24 hours. After that, true nature tends to emerge. Some nice, some not so much. #iaem15
ShelterBox training is very intense and designed to induce stress. #iaem15
ShelterBox Response team members are Logisticians, Case Workers, Diplomats, and Ambassadors.  #iaem15
ShelterBox has two kinds of volunteers: Ambassadors and Response Team members. #iaem15
40 ShelterBox employees in GB, 4 in US. Everybody else is volunteer. #iaem15
Next really big ShelterBox response was 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami. Deployed twice as many shelters as ever before. #iaem15
First big ShelterBox response was the 2001 earthquake. #iaem15
ShelterBox is a British charity, but has 20 affiliate countries, incorporated in those countries for PR and fundraising, #iaem15
ShelterBox "box" includes a tent and essential supplies for survival, including stove, kitchen items, and water purification system. #iaem15
ShelterBox was founded by a @Rotary club in Great Britain in 2000. #iaem15

Getting ready to watch @disaster_dave talk about @shelterboxus at #iaem15.
Pickles is the poster dog for @HopeAACR. If somebody says "Do you want Pickles?" in your disaster, think of her, not the food! #iaem15

Trauma tourists will also show up at your scene. Check credentials, go through proper channels to get legit people and dogs. #iaem15
"therapy ducks" and a "therapy pig" showed up at recent scenes. Not really trained for the job! #iaem15
Like other legit teams, qualified crisis response dog teams don't just show up. They come when they're called. #iaem15
Be sure to research qualified crisis dog teams BEFORE you need them. Legit ones will come with their own insurance. #iaem15
Crisis therapy dogs are not always an appropriate asset. Wildfires for instance create unhealthy working environments for them, #iaem15
I always find it slightly disconcerting to listen to somebody talk about a disaster I responded to. Not in a bad way tho. #iaem15
The better your relationship with a dog, the more relaxed your interaction with it will be. #iaem15
Some jerk is copying my tweets and passing them off as their own. #GetYourOwnTweets
HOPE Animal Assisted Crisis Response (@HopeAACR) can be called at any time, by any agency, at no charge. #iaem15
Crisis therapy dog teams work much shorter shifts than humans in disasters. Usually max of 4 hours. #iaem15
Dogs must be trained before being deployed. Must be trained and registered as a therapy team, then extra quals for crisis response. #iaem15
Interactions with animals: our heart rate and blood pressure drop. Makes us less anxious. Helps us focus on the present. #iaem15
Service dog is focused on the ONE they serve. Crisis dog focuses on everybody. #iaem15
Emotional phases of disaster: Pre-disaster, Impact, Heroic, Honeymoon, Disillusionment, Reconstruction. #iaem15
some research shows that the longer we're on shift, the more likely we are to think we can just keep going. #iaem15
Disaster stress can lead to impaired judgement and poor decision making. Can also cause compassion fatigue. #iaem15
Crisis stress management activities were activated withing just a few hours of the SR530 landslide happening. Critical element.  #iaem15
Q: how do you know you're stressed? A: I use "different" words. *laughter* #iaem15
The mere presence of a crisis response dog can break down barriers and get people talking. #iaem15
Crisis response dogs require training at both ends of the leash, mostly the human end. Dogs are already trained as therapy dogs. #iaem15
Do you know the difference between a service dog, a therapy dog, and a crisis response dog? #iaem15

@Plan_Prep_Live We use those force multipliers to get the word out. Agency I help during fire went from ~100 likes to 17K+ in a week.
@Plan_Prep_Live Yep. And real-time info is readily accessible via Facebook for those who seek it. We quit relying on FB push long ago.
@Plan_Prep_Live Part of that great engagement is through use of force multipliers, who watch for our messages and share them.
@Plan_Prep_Live I could tweet all day in my city and hardly anybody would see it. I get great engagement on FB posts tho.
@Plan_Prep_Live it really comes down to the comms plan a local agency has made and the research they've done on their audience.
@Plan_Prep_Live Your original post said EMs were going to quit using FB for breaking news. Different discussion than prep.
@Plan_Prep_Live Agreed, but preparedness is different than breaking news and requires different tactics.
@Plan_Prep_Live We saw this in the rural communities during wildland fires this summer.
@Plan_Prep_Live In communities that are big FB users, people will camp on the agency page to get the latest update.
@Plan_Prep_Live True, but that doesn't matter, since content only gets delivered to about 20% of likes anyway.
@Plan_Prep_Live Well, we will if that's what people in our community are using. If people watch our pages for updates, it works.

Big thanks to @FEMARegion10 , @hhsgov, @polaris_project for today’s webinar. Katherine Chon is a great speaker on human trafficking.
How to prevent human trafficking during disasters? Identify at-risk populations. Outreach to at-risk pops. Educate responders.
Japan earthquake/tsunami: homeless people recruited. Not fed/sheltered properly. Exposed to high radiation levels.
Haiti Earthquake: children exchanging sex for food and other basic needs.
Hurricane Katrina: domestic violence and sex assault in shelters. Pvt agencies trafficked labor workers from Thailand and other places.
2004 tsunami: increased reports of sexual violence and physical abuse, forced prostitution, abuse by aid workers.
Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act of 2005 requires actions to limit trafficking post-disaster.
How do natural disasters increase vulnerability to human trafficking? Unequal access to opportunities and unequal exposures to risk.
Traffickers sometimes tattoo or brand their victims.
Lack of awareness by general public contributes to human trafficking issues.
Lack of training for law enforcement, social services, healthcare workers contributes to victim inability to escape trafficking.
Some evidence shows LGBTQ youth are 5 times more likely to be victims of trafficking.
Trafficking victims are highly likely to encounter healthcare providers while being trafficked. 88% of domestic sex trafficking survivors.
Homeless and runaway youth are particularly vulnerable to human trafficking.
California study showed up to 80% of child trafficking victims were already part of the child welfare system.
Traffickers are purposeful in their recruitment. Looking for people who are disconnected from their support systems.
@Clim8Resilient live tweeting webinar!
Large proportion of sex trafficking victims are black, while labor trafficking victims are disproportionately Hispanic.
Majority of sex and labor trafficking victims are people of color.
@Clim8Resilient psych would fall under coercion.
National trafficking hotline accepts calls, texts, emails. 95k+ reports last year.
Heat map of trafficking reports. Many in Region 10.  http://t.co/blLjzh7MRU
Trafficking occurs in many places, often right in front of us. May even involve families or partners.  http://t.co/bTj2shGRKz
Trafficking involves the use of force, fraud, or coercion for the purposes of commercial sex work, labor, or services.
Many myths around human trafficking. It can be foreign or domestic workers. Can involve sex work and labor work.
Thanks @FEMARegion10 for hosting this webinar on human trafficking and emergency preparedness. Great info! #EMLife #ModernDaySlavery

Miller: EM is all about relationships. Need to have as many in advance as possible. #piepc
Miller: Resource ordering needs to have a process and you need to stick to it. #piepc
Miller: "who is in charge"needs to be worked out ahead of time. #piepc
Miller: lack of command depth was an issue. #piepc
@Jdlazo There are presentations for all of them. They may be for paying attendees only at this point, but I can get you a copy of this one.
Miller: You order it, you pay for it. Have a good system in place for order resources. #piepc
Miller: logistics of who gets what dontations is complex and needs to be planned for. #piepc
Miller: Hundreds of burned cattle became public health emergency. Able to remove from private property. #piepc
Poor burned baby bear photos. Many "ahhhs" from the crowd. "Cinder" will be released back to the wild soon tho. #piepc
Miller: 90% of disaster donations will be junk. Used underwear, high heels, bags of rags not useful. #piepc
Big shout outs to Southern Baptists, Soup Ladies, and WSART from Miller for Carlton Complex fires. #piepc
Miller: working with established volunteer groups will be a big help. They've been there and done that. #piepc
Miller: people will show up to help. They need a task, food, bathrooms, etc. #piepc
Mute your phone people! #piepc
Miller: train people how to treat others under pressure. #piepc
Miller: Abusive treatment is never justified. Collateral damage is never acceptable in the EM world. #piepc
Miller: Great leaders treat people with dignity and respect at all times. #piepc
@oremergencymgr Avg age of my team has probably dropped 20 years in the past 9. Very engaged group.
Miller: people handling is huge in an incident. Morale and stress are killers. #piepc
@oremergencymgr I think it's starting to shift back a bit though. Preppers and geeks are finding a great tool for various things.
@oremergencymgr You might be shocked by ham radio though. I did a testing session last year for 300ish, avg age 30.
@oremergencymgr It is a tool in the box though. In this case, it was a secondary or tertiary fallback. All else failed too.
Miller: the ham radio system in this fire failed due to people programs, not equipment failures. Lost comms w/critical area. #piepc
Miller: active rumor management is essential to response. Particularly on social media. #piepc
Miller: use all poss communications pathways. Neighbors/phone trees/EAS/ENS/Door-to-door/Radio/TV/Social Media/meetings/trap lines. #piepc
Miller: People expect to be made whole after a disaster, but that is never realistic. #piepc
@NWTEMC_PNW Yep, but locals who pay into a seperate entity sometimes forget that they still have responsibility. #piepc
Miller: Citizens have very high expectations of government that we often cannot meet. #piepc
Miller: Lots of people potentially in charge. Must define who does what in advance. #piepc
Miller: emergencies start and end locally. Local agencies must recognize their role and plan/train for it. #piepc
Miller: local cities must have a designated Emergency Manager and a plan. Need to function alone even when part of a shared entity. #piepc
Miller: your briefing rooms need conference call capability. Huddling around somebody's cell phone with the speaker on doesn't work. #piepc
Miller: you can't put everything in one room. Don't co-locate EOC/call center/lunch room/policy rooms. #piepc
Miller: Also needed a lot more people to rotated through EOC. Needed outside IMT team. #piepc
Miller: EOC in ops capacity required depth of ICS training (300 + 400) plus experience. Not enough people qualified. #piepc
Miller: IMTs were focused on firefighting. EOC had an ops function, not just support. Evacs, water checks, feeding, all done by EOC. #piepc
Miller: The EOC takes on a much larger role in big disaster. It requires more people, stuff, and info than you ever imagined, #piepc

@caroldn heh. Mines buzzes, hard to ignore!
@caroldn though for the record, I don't think we fundamentally disagree. Just diff approaches to same core issue.
@caroldn I enjoy debating with you! Always logical and factual, which I appreciate. Makes it much more pleasant to disagree peacefully!
@caroldn that's precisely why my pub ed is now focused on low income and other vulnerable. They benefit the most, have greatest need.
@caroldn good point! Still not a quick or easy solution. Takes long-term commitment and change.
@caroldn just saying there has to be a common sense approach that allows greatest good for greatest number.
@caroldn creates confusion though. We say "no pop-up shelters" and then we say "unless you're non-compliant, then go ahead, but no support"
@caroldn great for getting in, but narrow halls and small bathrooms can't be quickly fixed.
@caroldn that's exactly my point! Plans need to reflect reality of what will really happen and acknowledge what we're working toward.
@caroldn not here! My only concern really is for the big one since I know resources will quickly be tapped.
@caroldn we can't support unofficial shelters, so non-accessible community buildings are on their own. Counterintuitive to helping people.
@caroldn the issue is that I can't house enough people in the buildings we own. If we can't rely on community, people go unsheltered.
@caroldn plus I need to work and stuff.
@caroldn heh. Yep!
@caroldn silly to tell a non-accessible church that they're not allowed to provide refuge and must leave people out in the cold.
@caroldn example: all city buildings are accessible. Shelters potentially in non-city buildings though. We have no control over them.
@caroldn we do build that way now (solution in progress) but much old building stock still in use.
@caroldn 2) other people are willing to step up and help those who need it. I don't think it's unsolved. I think the solutions are in play.
@caroldn two reasons. 1) People live longer with disabilities now. Didn't used to be the large-scale issue that it is now.  And . . .
@caroldn I live by "do the most good for the most people" and if I have to use a building that isn't compliant, I will make it work.
@caroldn I just don't understand the "if we can't help everyone, we're not allowed to help anyone" mentality. Morally, it's reprehensible.
@caroldn agreed! I think the public is smarter than government though and will find ways to make it work without our meddling.
@caroldn I hate that. I understand need to be ADA compliant, but to ban all from an otherwise viable shelter is silly and can cause harm.

@caroldn @CherylBle I am!

@sfDEMrob @CherylBle we are using concept of "what do you already have" for preparedness education. New mindset, more empowering.
@caroldn bottom line is plenty of people to tell EM what we must do. Few willing to invest time our money into helping though.
@caroldn public transport critical since many with different abilities rely on it and all will need transport to DRC.
@caroldn but how to fix? No budgets and can't require partners to fix theirs. Feds face created no-win situation.
@caroldn Imagine PR nightmare: "City refuses to open public facility as shelter, fearing DOJ lawsuit". Why punish all when some can benefit?
@caroldn Why should I have to exclude people from usable buildings when some CAN use them? Why not let them serve the people they can?
@caroldn Yes it is, but DOJ doesn't recognize regional efforts and will pass judgement upon locals for what they're doing locally.
@caroldn That's all well and good, but I don't have any more buildings! City has no more, schools have no generators. So 100 is our limit.
@caroldn And that being the case, I can only shelter .0014% of my population. All other buildings must remain empty. DOJ's call, not mine.
@caroldn Missing the point again! DOJ doesn't recognize that difference. All shelters must provide all services according to them.
@caroldn Exactly. All others could stay there, but because some can't, I'm in violation, even though I have other places for them.
@CherylBle Maybe you should give up flying!
@caroldn DOJ doesn't care about critical diffs, only diffs. Mine is missing showers, transit routes, generator switch, med care.
@caroldn All meet their requirements for day to day use, but none were built to be emergency shelters. Emergency use is the issue.
@caroldn Missing the point! All my buildings are ADA compliant, but they cannot provide the same services to all as emergency shelters.
@caroldn Sure, but that's not what DOJ cares about. They want every person to have equal access at every shelter site. Not possible.
@caroldn not saying I can't or won't help, just that DOJ is likely to sue us for planning for it since we can't provide equality for all
@caroldn don't get me wrong, I can provide great service to those extra .002%, just not in a way that will satisfy the DOJ.
@caroldn By acknowledging that additional .002% though, makes me subject to DOJ sanctions. No fix for me, as no addl facilities or $$$.
@caroldn Perspective: 5 years ago, I could shelter 0% of my population. Now, in a DOJ compliant way, .0014%. Non-compliant: .0035%.
@caroldn I see that we've made huge strides, both in thinking and capacity/capability. All that could be squished in an instant by DOJ.
@caroldn There hasn't been an EM community for all that many decades! I guess sitting on mass care task force, I have diff outlook than you.
@sfDEMrob I meant Congress staffers heard, not DOJ. Agree that they ought to go out and try doing the dirty one once or twice.
